data.title: Whirlpool (1935)
data.meta_description: The happiness of a newly-married couple, Henry and Jeannie Saint Clair, is shattered when the husband is made a paralytic in an automobile accident. The wife still loves him, although he is incapable of any physical love. She is slowly drawn into a short-lived affair with a handsome athlete, Robert Vanier. When the husband learns of the affair, he commits suicide. But the wife cannot forget him and she sends her lover away.
data.text:
Newlyweds on the honeymoon get into a car accident. The husband (Jean Galland) is seriously injured and left impotent. The wife (Jeanne Boitel) who loves him is left sexually frustrated and falls into an affair with her best girlfriend's handsome boyfriend. The girlfriend's mother (Françoise Rosay) stumbles on the lovers and the husband finds out with tragic results.

Directed by Edmond T. Gréville almost as a silent film. There's lots of cutting back and forth between longing glances. The film is filled with water imagery with frequent cuts to roiling waters. To add to the metaphor, the impotent (and that word is used explicitly in the dialogue) husband is an engineer working on a dam project. The husband walks with…
